In Julia, Write a function `wrap_string`. It iterates over words and it will add a new line each time a maximum `text_width::Int=10` would be exceeded. Provide an example

```
function wrap_string(s::AbstractString, text_width::Int = 10)
    # split the string into words
    words = split(s)
    # create a new string with each word separated by a space
    wrapped_text = join(words, " ")
    # check if the width of the text exceeds the maximum width
    while length(wrapped_text) > text_width
        # find the last whitespace character in the string
        i = findlast(isspace, wrapped_text)
        # if no whitespace character is found, break the loop
        if i == nothing
            break
        end
        # replace the whitespace character with a newline character
        wrapped_text = replace(wrapped_text[1:i-1], " ", "\n")
    end
    return wrapped_text
end
```
Example usage:
```julia
s = "This is an example string that needs to be wrapped"
wrapped_string = wrap_string(s, 5)
println(wrapped_string) # prints "This is\nan example\nstring that\nneeds to\nbe wrapped"
```
